newsitem.title: POLAND: FORECAST - POLISH REPO/REVREPO SEEN DOWN BY END-97.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - POLISH REPO/REVREPO SEEN DOWN BY END-97.

text.p: Banks expect liquidity on the money market, long on the surplus side, would shrink this year, shifting the focus of open market operations from reverse repos to repos, a Reuter poll of Poland's 25 biggest banks showed.

Banks predicted the National Bank of Poland's 14-day revrepo rate, last at 21.64 percent, would fall to 18.15 percent by year-end. The forecast is a mean average of banks' predictions ranging from 16.20 to 20.75 percent.
Banks expected the reverse repo rate to ease to 21.53 percent on average this month and to 17.70 percent in January 1998.
However, six of the polled banks did not expect the central bank to stage such operations at the end of the year predicting it would rather do repos.
Six banks expected the central bank would do both repos and reverse repos at the end of 1997 and six expected the NBP would stage only repo operations.
The repo rate at the end of 1997 was seen at 18.56 percent on average with a range of predictions from 16.5 to 21.5 percent.
The rate was seen at 22.17 percent on average this month with a range of 20.15 to 24.5 percent and falling to 18.15 percent in 12 months time -- in January 1998 within a range of 16 to 21.5 percent.
